questions.text: The marrow cavity in the shaft of the fetal long bone mainly contains _____.
questions.solution:
The marrow cavity in the shaft of the fetal long bone mainly contains red marrow.

Bone marrow is a soft, pulpy tissue found in the marrow cavity and the spaces of spongy bone. It is mainly of two types:

  1. Yellow marrow - made up predominantly of fat cells and may contain few islands of hemopoietic tissue. It is seen in the shaft of the long bones of an adult.
  2. Red marrow - It is made up predominantly of hemopoietic tissue. It is seen throughout the skeleton of the fetus. It persists till about five years of age after which, the red marrow in the shaft of long bones is gradually replaced by the yellow marrow. By around 20-25 years of age, the sites where the red marrow persists include:
    • Vertebrae
    • Sternum
    • Ribs
    • Clavicles
    • Scapulae
    • Pelvis
    • Cranial bones
    • Proximal ends of femur and humerus

The term gelatinous marrow refers to the degenerated bone marrow in the cranial bones, seen in old age. There is no white marrow.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female is found in a semiconscious state. On initial evaluation, her CBG is 23mg/dL. Her parents tell that the patient is an athlete and was trying to gain weight recently. An evaluation of which of the following will help in establishing a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette strongly suggests hypoglycemia due to surreptitious use of exogenous insulin, characterized by a low C-peptide level.

Insulin abuse is a method for increasing muscle bulk and performance enhancement in athletes, although less common than anabolic steroid abuse. Exogenous insulin does not contain C-peptide. Therefore blood level of C-peptide will be low in such patients. On the other hand, endogenous production of insulin will be characterized by high C-peptide level in blood.

 

Insulin is composed of two chains A and B, and a connecting peptide called C peptide. The insulin and C peptide are packaged in the secretory granules and secreted in equimolar amounts. 

Importance of C-peptide:

  • C peptide is measured by radioimmunoassay, and its level in the blood provides an index of beta-cell function in patients receiving exogenous insulin. If they are unable to produce insulin, they have greatly decreased levels of C peptide.
  • C peptide levels can be used to differentiate between an insulinoma (high C-peptide) and exogenous insulin overdose (low C-peptide) in a patient with hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is also considered a hormone?
questions.solution:
Vitamin D is also considered a hormone.

Vitamin D encompasses a group of sterols, which have a hormone-like function.

Functions of vitamin D:

  • Regulation of calcium and phosphate: It increased blood calcium and phosphate level
  • Immunomodulatory action: Vitamin D increases the ability of the innate immune system to fight against pathogens
  • Antiproliferative: Because of the antiproliferative function, deficiency (<20ng/ml) is associated with an increased incidence of colon cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer
  • Bone development

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a liver biopsy specimen from a patient with liver disease. The following finding is noted. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows hepatic macro-vesicular steatosis along with intraparenchymal cholestasis, which is suggestive of fatty liver. This condition can occur due to alcoholism.

The lipid accumulates in the hepatocytes as vacuoles. These vacuoles have a clear appearance on hematoxylin and eosin staining.

A few causes of fatty liver are as follows:

  • Alcoholism - most common cause in developed countries
  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) - associated with diabetes and obesity
  • Toxins
  • Malnutrition
  • Dyslipidemia
  • Anoxia

Fatty change is mostly seen in the liver because it is the major organ involved in fat metabolism. It may also occur in the heart, muscles, and kidneys.

The most common form of lipid accumulation is triglycerides. Other forms of lipid that can be accumulated include cholesterol, cholesterol esters, and phospholipids.

questions.text: A 52-year-old requires a kidney transplant due to chronic kidney disease. Her 2 children match her HLA type 4/6 and 5/6 respectively. On what chromosome is this match protein sequence located?
questions.solution:
HLA complex of genes is located on the short arm of chromosome 6 (chromosome 6p21).

The human leukocyte antigen (HLA) system or complex is a gene complex encoding the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins. It consists of 3 separate clusters of genes:

  • Class I– A, B and C loci 
  • Class II– DR, DQ and DP loci
  • Class III– Complement C2 and C4 of classical pathway and properdin factor B of the alternate pathway, heat shock proteins(HSP), TNF α and β.

questions.text: A young man who collapsed at a concert was suspected to have bacterial meningitis. The other attendees of the concert were administered ciprofloxacin by the medical staff on duty. What is this kind of antimicrobial therapy called?
questions.solution:
The antimicrobial treatment initiated in a patient who is not yet infected is called prophylactic therapy. The goal is to prevent infection in some patients and to prevent dangerous manifestations of infections in other patients. 

Option A: Preemptive therapy is therapy in an asymptomatic individual with evidence of infection (high-risk).

Option C: Empirical therapy is broad-spectrum therapy in a patient with symptoms of infection but no microbiological confirmation of the causative agent. 

Option D: Suppressive therapy is given to patients when the infection is controlled but not completely eradicated by the initial round of antimicrobial treatment. This is usually indicated for immunosuppressed patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is an early sign of death?
questions.solution:
Rigor mortis is an early sign of death. 

Immediate signs of death (somatic death):

  • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
  • Cessation of respiration
  • Cessation of circulation

Early signs of death (cellular death):

  • Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
  • Eye changes
  • Primary flaccidity of muscles
  • Cooling of the body
  • Postmortem lividity/suggilation
  • Rigor mortis

Late signs of death:

  • Putrefaction
  • Adipocere
  • Mummification

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the signs and symptoms of the condition represented below?
questions.solution:
The X-ray reveals enlarged adenoids, indicating a diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy. Patients present with a flattened or absent nasolabial fold, not a prominent one.

Clinical features:

  • Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitis, and epistaxis.
  • Bilateral conductive hearing loss and serous otitis media due to eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice.
  • Adenoid facies - elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.
  • Sleep apnoea - chronic cases lead to hypoxemia and pulmonary vasoconstriction. This consequently leads to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Aprosexia - lack of concentration.

Treatment of adenoid hypertrophy follows both medical and surgical approaches. Medical management includes antibiotics for acute infections, antiallergic measures, and nasal decongestants. However, adenoidectomy remains the definitive treatment when medical management fails or in cases with persistent symptoms.

The surgical indications include:

  • Chronic nasal obstruction
  • Chronic mouth breathing
  • Recurrent otitis media
  • Sleep apnea
  • Failure to thrive

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
The most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy is the duration of diabetes.

The 2nd most important factor for the development of retinopathy is glycemic control.

Diabetic retinopathy is more common in type 1 diabetes mellitus. 

First fundus examination for type 1 diabetes is done after 5 years and type 2, at the time of diagnosis. The frequency of follow-up for types 1 and 2 is every year and diabetes in pregnancy is every 3 months.

The earliest feature of diabetic retinopathy is microaneurysms, which are present in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most logical sequence?
questions.solution:
Disease → Impairment → Disability → Handicap is the most logical sequence among the given options.

Disease is a state of physiological/psychological dysfunction.

Impairment is any loss or abnormality in normal structure or function.

Disability is the inability to carry out normal actions due to impairment.

Handicap is the disadvantage due to disability that limits fulfilment of a role that is normal.

questions.text: What is the dosage of vitamin A given for a 2-year-old baby with keratomalacia?

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week
2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
The recommended vitamin A dosage for a 2-year-old child with keratomalacia is 2,00,000 IU given immediately, followed by the same age-specific dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU in 9 doses given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5 years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-11 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is predominantly responsible for the disinfecting property of bleaching powder?
questions.solution:
The disinfectant property of bleaching powder is predominantly due to the action of hypochlorous acid.

Bleaching powder, also known as chlorinated lime (CaOCl2), has 33 per cent of chlorine in it. When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids. The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water. The hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions, as follows:

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

HOCl → H + OCl

The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid. It is 70-80 times more effective than Hypochlorite ion.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for large scale purification of water and for drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • Alongside its anti-pathogenic attributes, it oxidizes iron, manganese and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odor producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • Action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    • Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water which contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorines.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors caused due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorines separately.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with wheezing after taking aspirin for a headache. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Positive skin test for inhaled allergens

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of aspirin-sensitivity asthma. It is closely associated with nasal polyps.

Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), also known as Samter’s triad or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It is a chronic medical condition that consists of:

  • Intrinsic asthma
  • Recurrent sinus disease with nasal polyps
  • Sensitivity to aspirin and other NSAIDs

It has normal serum IgE levels and a negative skin test for inhaled allergens.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man has come to the emergency complaining of a burning type of chest pain. Comment on his ECG recording shown below.
questions.solution:
The above ECG strip shows normal sinus rhythm.

The features in this ECG that suggest this diagnosis are as follows:

  • The QRS complexes are narrow (<120 ms or 3 small squares) which implies that the impulse is supraventricular and is conducted via the normal conduction pathway.

 

  • Each QRS complex is preceded by a P wave. This means that all the atrial depolarizations that arise in the sinus node are conducted to the ventricles.

 

  • The PR interval is constant for all the impulses and is normal (<200 ms) in duration.

 

  • The RR interval is constant which implies a regular rhythm.

questions.text: In patients with sarcoidosis, which of the following is the most commonly affected organ?
questions.solution:
Sarcoidosis most commonly affects the lungs.

Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. It commonly involves the lungs, skin, liver, and eyes.

questions.text: You observed the following finding in a patient in the OPD. Which among the following conditions is least likely to cause this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows digital clubbing. Among the given options, aortic dissection is least likely to cause digital clubbing.

Clubbing is a selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes due to the proliferation of connective tissue, particularly on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Chronic interstitial pneumonitis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Diffuse pulmonary disease - pulmonary fibrosis, asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease (Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease)
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Neoplasms - esophagus, liver, bowel
    • Cirrhosis - juvenile and biliary
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Subacute bacterial endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous fistula
    • Patent Ductus arteriosus
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism (Grave’s disease)
    • Thyroid acropachy
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)
  • Skin disease
    • Palmoplantar keratoderma
    • Fischer-Volavsek syndrome.
  • Malignancies
    • Thyroid cancer
    • Thymus cancer
    • Hodgkin disease
    • Disseminated chronic myeloid leukemia.

Note: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) does not cause clubbing. If clubbing is present in a patient with COPD, underlying lung cancer and bronchiectasis must be ruled out.

questions.text: An infant delivered at full-term by normal vaginal delivery, presented with respiratory distress immediately after birth. Chest X-ray showed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

The common clinical presentation is as follows:

  • Respiratory distress
  • Dextrocardia
  • Scaphoid abdomen

Prenatal diagnosis is done by ultrasonography. Lung-to-head ratio (LHR) is used to assess severity in patients with left-sided CDH. An LHR value of <1 is associated with a very poor prognosis, whereas an LHR >1.4 predicts a more favourable outcome.

Option A: Hyaline membrane disease is a syndrome in premature infants caused by developmental insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs.

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome is the aspiration of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, which can occur before, during or immediately after birth. Meconium is the first intestinal discharge from newborns, a viscous, dark-green substance composed of intestinal epithelial cells, lanugo, mucus, and intestinal secretions.

Option D: During normal delivery, the compression of the rib cage while passing through the mother's vaginal canal helps to remove fluid from the lungs. However, newborns who are delivered via cesarean birth may have excess fluid in the lungs and therefore be hypoxic and develop transient tachypnea.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: The most common salivary gland to develop stones is______.
questions.solution:
80% of salivary gland stones occur in the submandibular gland and are mostly radioopaque.

Sialolithiasis:

  • It is less common in the parotid gland (20%) than in the submandibular gland (80%), leading to sialadenitis.
  • Parotid duct stones are usually radiolucent and rarely visible on plain radiography.
  • They are frequently located at the confluence of the collecting ducts or located in the distal aspect of the parotid duct adjacent to the parotid papilla.
  • Parotid gland sialography is usually required to identify the stone.
  • A stone located in the collecting duct or within the gland may be managed by either endoscopic retrieval, or lithotripsy; in rare cases, surgical removal via a parotidectomy approach may be required.
  • In the case of sialadenitis, treatment is either marsupialization or total excision of the gland.

questions.text: Identify the following incision used for appendicectomy.
questions.solution:
• Lanz incision is a Transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis,2 cm below the  umbilicus, centred on the midclavicular–midinguinal line
  • Rockey–Davis incision : Transverse right lower quadrant incision.
  • Gridiron incision : Oblique muscle splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. Also called as Mc Burney incision.
  • Rutherford–Morrison incision : oblique muscle cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity)

questions.text: The diagnosis based on the gross picture of Gall bladder is
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of the gallbladder is of Cholesterolosis Gallbladder also known as Strawberry gallbladder.

It reveals:

  • Brick red GB mucosa with Bright yellow flecks of lipid.
  • Multiple cholesterol polyps studding the gallbladder wall.

questions.text: IUCD having the longest life span is _____________
questions.solution:
CuT 380 A has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paraguard): It is named so for the 380 mm2 of copper surface area. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. Hence the Copper T-380A has been able to achieve superior contraception while maintaining a similar side-effect profile

The Copper T-380A has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the life span of the Copper T-380A.

The frame of the Copper T-380A is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

IUCD Life span
Cu T 380A 10 years
CuT 200 3 years
Multi loaded Cu 250  3 years
LNG IUS /Mirena

5 years
Progestasert 1 year
Nova-T 5 years

questions.text: The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism includes all except _____.
questions.solution:
The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism includes the following:

  • Hypotension
  • Hypoxia
  • Severe consumptive coagulopathy 

Predisposing conditions:

  • Rapid labor
  • Meconium-stained amniotic fluid
  • Tears into uterine and other large pelvic veins
  • Older maternal age
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Labor induction or augmentation
  • Eclampsia
  • Cesarean/forceps/vacuum delivery
  • Placental abruption/placenta previa
  • Hydramnios 

Clinical picture:

Late stage of labor/immediate postpartum: Sudden gasping for air → Sudden seizures/cardiorespiratory arrest→ massive hemorrhage due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: You are monitoring uterine contractions in a primigravida at 38 weeks in labor.  You find that the uterine contractions are uncoordinated and frequency is about 6 contractions in 10 minutes. Which of the following is not true regarding your finding?

choices.text: It is common in nulliparous labour
Management includes wait and watch policy

questions.solution:
The given clinical finding is suggestive of uterine tachysystole and oxytocin administration is not beneficial in tachysystole (Hypertonic uterine dysfunction.)

Tachysystole (Hypertonic uterine dysfunction)

  • The uterine contractions are incoordinated and increased in frequency (>5 contractions in 10 minutes) without rest in between and also increase in the baseline tone.
  • It is associated with late active phase dysfunction (not latent). i.e. when cervix is almost 7 cm dilated.
  • The most common cause is occipito posterior. Hence, wait and watch policy is adopted.
  • More common in nulliparous females
  • Oxytocin administration leads to hyperstimulation of uterus. Hence not recommended.

Hypotonic uterine dysfunction:

  • The uterine contractions are inadequate.
  • It is associated with early active phase.
  • More common in nulliparous females.

questions.text: A premature newborn infant is found to have a systolic murmur with late accentuation over the left infraclavicular area. This is due to the patency of ________
questions.solution:
A systolic murmur with late accentuation/ continuous murmur heard in premature infants is usually due to patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

In fetal life, the patency of ductus arteriosus is maintained by low oxygen tension and endogenously produced prostaglandins. In a full-term neonate, oxygen is the most important factor controlling the duct closure. In normal neonates, functionally ductal closure completes by 10-15 hours after birth. However, in premature infants, patent ductus arteriosus is common especially with the context of respiratory distress syndrome.

Note:

Gestational age also appears to play an important role; the ductus of a premature infant is less responsive to oxygen, even though its musculature is developed. Hence, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is more common in premature infants.

Other options:

  • VSD: Loud, harsh or blowing holo-systolic murmur present over the left sternal border, frequently accompanied by thrill.
  • PFO/ASD: Characteristic is the wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound. An ejection systolic murmur could be heard over the left sternal border.

questions.text: A ligament is marked in red in the given image below. According to the Denis three-column concept of spinal stability, the given ligament comes under which column?
questions.solution:
The given ligament marked in red is the posterior longitudinal ligament. It is a component of the middle column.

Denis three-column concept of spinal stability: This was used to describe the classification of spinal injuries.

    • Anterior column:
    • Anterior half of the vertebral body
    • Anterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Anterior longitudinal ligament
  • Middle column:
    • Posterior half of the vertebral body
    • Posterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Posterior longitudinal ligament
  • Posterior column
    • Pedicles
    • Facet joints
    • Posterior bony arch
    • Interspinous ligament
    • Supraspinous ligament

The fractures involving the middle column and at least one other column are regarded as unstable injuries i.e. there is a significant risk of displacement of the vertebral components, leading to damage of the neural tissues.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement with respect to the X-ray shown below.

choices.text: The structure marked number 2 is the right ventricular border
The structure marked 1 is the trachea
The structure marked 3 is the left ventricular border
The structure marked 4 is the aortic arch

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is option A because the structure marked as 2 is the right atrial border (not the right ventricular border). The given image is posteroanterior (PA) view of a normal chest x-ray. Structures marked in the X-Ray are as follows:

  1. Trachea
  2. Right atrial border
  3. Left ventricular border
  4. Aortic arch

Chest x-rays can be described as posteroanterior (PA) or anteroposterior (AP) views. This indicates the direction in which the x-ray beam traverses from the patient to the detector.

PA view means that the x-ray beam enters from the posterior aspect of the patient and exits anteriorly to reach the film.

AP view means that the x-ray beam enters the patient from the anterior aspect and exits from the posterior aspect, reaching the film.

A left lateral decubitus view is one taken with the patient’s left side down.

questions.text: A patient being treated with Phenelzine came to the emergency department with headache, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis following dinner at the restaurant and his  BP is 190/120.  The patient is diagnosed with a cheese reaction. Consumption of any of the following foods could have caused cheese reaction except:
questions.solution:
Cheese reaction is seen on consumption on tyramine rich foods such as cheese, red wine, aged meat, and fish, etc. Apples do not cause a cheese reaction.

Cheese reaction occurs in patients being treated with MAO inhibitors who consume tyramine rich foods. Inhibition of the MAO-A isoform prevents the metabolism of dietary tyramine in the gut, thus allowing intact tyramine to enter the circulation. A hypertensive crisis occurs as a result of a powerful pressor effect of tyramine. 

The hypertensive crisis in cheese rection is treated with Phentolamine.

questions.text: A junior resident, during his first emergency room duty, comes across a patient with difficulty in breathing. Since he was not confident to do endotracheal intubation, He tries to secure the airway with the following device. All of the following are the advantages associated with the use of this device when compared with tracheal intubation except:
questions.solution:
This given image is of Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA). The disadvantage associated with its use is that there is an increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration when compared with tracheal intubation.

The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that sits in the hypopharynx and partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions, but not gastric regurgitation.

Advantages and disadvantages of the laryngeal mask airway compared with tracheal intubation are: 

Advantages:

  • Easy and rapid
  • Less invasive
  • Better hemodynamic stability
  • Very useful in difficult intubations
  • Less tooth and laryngeal trauma
  • Does not require muscle relaxation
  • Does not require neck mobility 
  • No risk of esophageal or endobronchial intubation

Disadvantages:

  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of gas leak and pollution
  • Can cause gastric distention

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the image given below ?

choices.text: Most common manifestation of nail psoriasis
Most specific sign of nail psoriasis
Most common manifestation of Lichen Planus of the nail
Most specific sign of Lichen Planus of the nail

questions.solution:
The above clinical image depicting Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus.

The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

 

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Trachonychia

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI image given above is T1 weighted.

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense and white matter is white whereas In T2 images CSF is bright/hyperintense and white matter is dark.

Other options:

  • In FLAIR images CSF and white matter is dark.
  • FLAIR (fluid attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid.
  • STIR (Short tau inversion recovery) is done to detect bone marrow oedema.

FLAIR:
